title: Highlights From My Notes From A Forensic Psychiatry Conference Last Week
summary:
Key ideas
- The insanity defense is not overused.
- A successful plea of insanity results in a longer confinement in forensic hospitals than in prisons for sane felons.
- Juries are not allowed to be informed about what will happen to defendants if they return a certain verdict.
- Forensic psychiatrists are effective at determining which criminals who plead insanity are “faking it”.
- Real mentally retarded people perform at chance on medium and difficult multiple-choice vocabulary test questions.

Key learnings
- The insanity defense is not a good legal strategy due to its low success rate and the increase in the time spent in confinement.
- The general public has a false perception of what happens to felons found insane due to legal restrictions on juries.
- Forensic psychiatrists have become adept at identifying fake claims of mental illness, making it difficult for criminals to successfully plead insanity.
- Real mentally retarded people perform at chance on medium and difficult lexical questions and are easily distinguishable from fakers.

Key questions
- Why do so few cases use the insanity defense despite the popular belief of its overuse?
- What can be done to ensure juries have complete information when making their verdicts?
- How can the public's perception of how the legal system deals with felons found insane be corrected?
- What are the implications of advancements in forensic psychiatry on the legal field, particularly on the use of the insanity defense?
- What other factors should be considered when vetting potential jurors for capital cases?
